results.justification: The document explicitly states the research methodology, focusing on a goal-setting intervention using a conversational agent to examine the effects of guidance and feedback. (e.g., 'Our primary research question was: What is the effect of guidance and feedback on the quality and attainment of self-set academic goals over time?')

Section 2.3 provides a detailed, step-by-step description of the experimental procedure, including participant recruitment, data collection, and the timeline of activities. (e.g., 'Data collection for this experiment took place across a 5-week period coinciding with a single semester of the participants degree.')

The document states: 'An extensive overview of the experimental procedure of this study, alongside additional information about the goal quality and feedback allocation workflows can be found at the attached OSF link (https://osf.io/gwxe5/?view_only=2c3cf672fff24d4581d983d38f4f8b87).'
Data is shared via OSF link.

Section 2.2 details the measures used (SRL skills, self-efficacy, perfectionism, goal quality, goal attainment, goal striving) and provides information about their scales and reliability (e.g., 'The questionnaire consisted of six subscales measured on a 5-point Likert scale ranging from 1 (strongly disagree) to 5 (strongly agree) including goal setting (5-items,U = .75)...').

Section 2.2 describes the data collection methods for each measure, including the questionnaires used and how they were administered. (e.g., 'SRL skills were measured using the Online Self- regulated Learning Questionnaire (OSLQ)...')
The document does not mention the availability of analysis code in an open repository.
The document does not mention the availability of code for data preparation.

The document clearly describes the statistical tests used (ANOVA, ANCOVA) and mentions the use of covariates. (e.g., 'To answer the first research question, a mixed method Analysis of Variance (ANOVA) was run.')
Effect sizes (partial eta squared) and p-values are reported throughout the results section. (e.g., 'F(3,55) = 18.616, p < .001.')

The document includes a thematic analysis of user feedback, providing subjective context and interpretation. (e.g., 'A thematic analysis was done on these answers to group them into overarching feedback points provided by participants.')

The process of thematic analysis is described, and key themes are presented with illustrative quotes. (e.g., 'Overall, 68 (87.2%) of participants gave some form of feedback in the open response feedback question provided at the end of the study.')
The results are presented in a clear and organized manner, with tables summarizing descriptive statistics and statistical test results. (e.g., Table 1 and Table 2)

Section 3.4 discusses limitations of the study, including the sample's characteristics and potential participation bias. (e.g., 'The sample was drawn from the general population of a social sciences department...')
The document does not explicitly mention or provide a link to a preregistration.
